Writing readable code because other people might need to use your code.
Writing readable code because you might need to use your code, a few weeks/months/years after you‚Äôve written it.
Put spaces between and around variable names and operators (=+-*/).
Break up long lines of code.
Keeping a consistent style.

title: R OBJECTS
text:
R Object

In R, everything you create or work with is stored as an object.
Objects can be numbers, text, data tables, functions, or even plots.
Think of an object as a named container that stores information in your R environment.

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Common Types of R Objects

Vector ‚Äì a sequence of values (same type)


numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)     # Numeric vector

names <- c("Asha", "Raj", "Zara")  # Character vector

names

[1] "Asha" "Raj"  "Zara"








Curious Candy üç¨üç≠üç¨


Why are we not seeing numbers in the results?

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Common Types of R Objects

Matrix ‚Äì 2D table of numbers


mymatrix <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2)

mymatrix

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
[2,]    2    4    6

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Common Types of R Objects

Data Frame ‚Äì table with rows and columns (like Excel)


mydata <- data.frame(
  Name = c("Ali", "Beena"),
  Age = c(25, 30)
)




mydata

   Name Age
1   Ali  25
2 Beena  30

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Common Types of R Objects

List ‚Äì collection of different types of objects

A list can contain vectors, numbers, strings, even other lists.




mylist <- list(name = "Sara", scores = c(90, 85, 88), passed = TRUE)

mylist

$name
[1] "Sara"

$scores
[1] 90 85 88

$passed
[1] TRUE

title: R OBJECTS
R OBJECTS
text:
üí°Guidelines to ‚Äúname‚Äù R Objects:

A name cannot start with a number.
A name cannot use some special symbols, like ^, !, $, @, +, -, /, or *,:.
Avoid caps.
Avoid space.
Use dash (like weight-kg) or underscore (like weight_kg).
If chronology matters then add date (2020-09-05-file-name).

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Comment:

Writing comments in R code (or any programming language) is essential for making your code understandable, maintainable, and collaborative.
Comments are lines in the code that are not executed; they‚Äôre used to explain what the code does, why certain decisions were made, and how to use or modify the code.

title: R OBJECTS
section: How to Write Comments in R
text:
How to Write Comments in R

Use # to begin a comment.
R ignores everything after the # on that line.



# This is a comment

x <- 5  # This sets x to 5

title: R OBJECTS
section: Why Comments Are Important in R
text:
Why Comments Are Important in R

Improves Readability

Helps you and others understand the logic quickly, especially after some time.

Supports Collaboration

Team members can follow your logic and contribute more easily.

Eases Debugging and Maintenance

Clear comments make it easier to find and fix issues or update code.

Documents Assumptions and Logic

Explains why certain steps are performed in a specific way.

title: R OBJECTS
text:
Examples


üõë Bad Practice: No Comments

```{r}
#| eval: false

a <- read.csv("data.csv")
b <- a[a$score > 80, ]
c <- mean(b$score)
```

üôÅ This code works, but it‚Äôs not clear what it‚Äôs doing or why.

‚úÖ Better Version With Comments

```{r}
#| eval: false

# Read data from CSV file
data <- read.csv("data.csv")

# Filter rows where score is greater than 80
high_scores <- data[data$score > 80, ]

# Calculate average of the high scores
avg_score <- mean(high_scores$score)
```

title: CODE CHUNKS
text:
Code Chunk


A code chunk is a section of code inside your Quarto (.qmd) document that gets executed when you render the document. The output (like a table or plot) is shown right in the final HTML, PDF, or Word file.

title: CODE CHUNKS
section: Basic Syntax of an R Code Chunk
text:
Basic Syntax of an R Code Chunk


```{r}

```


Starts and ends with triple back ticks (```).
{r} tells Quarto it‚Äôs an R code chunk.

title: CODE CHUNKS
text:
Simple Calculation


```{r}

5 + 7

```

This will print the result 12 in the rendered document.

title: CODE CHUNKS
text:
Plot


```{r}

plot(cars)

```

This shows a plot of the built-in cars dataset.

title: CODE CHUNKS
text:
Code chunks (or cells or blocks)
Three ways to insert code chunks in the quarto file:

Keyboard shortcuts:

for  Option + Cmd + i.
for  ctrl + alt + i.

 Insert Chunk button in the editor toolbar.
Manually type the chunk delimiters ```{r} and ```.



Source: Jadey Ryan‚Äôs Talk

title: CODE CHUNKS
text:
Code chunks (or cells or blocks)
Two ways to run code chunks:


Use the Run Current Chunk or Run All Chunks Above buttons.
Run the current code chunk with Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + Enter.



Source: Jadey Ryan‚Äôs Talk

title: QUARTO
section: Process When You Render the Quarto Document
text:
Process When You Render the Quarto Document

Quarto sends the .qmd file to knitr, which executes all of the code chunks and creates a new markdown (.md) document which includes the code and its output. The markdown file generated by knitr is then processed by pandoc, which is responsible for creating the finished file.

\]

\[
10 + \frac{2\times16}{8} - 5
\]


Answer: 9

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Let‚Äôs Understand this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x_i
\]

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Let‚Äôs Understand this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x_i \\ = 10 + 6 \\ = 16
\]

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n x^2_i
\]

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \right )^2
\]

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Let‚Äôs Try this
\[
\left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \right )^2 \\ = (10+6)^2 \\ = 16^2 \\ = 256
\]

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Scales of Measurement:


The scales of measurement are a way to classify data based on their attributes and the mathematical operations that can be performed on them.

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Scales of Measurement:
They are classified into four types:

Nominal scale.
Ordinal scale.
Interval scale.
Ratio scale.

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Nominal Scale

Categorizes data without any order or rank.








Image Source: Voxco

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
ü§Ø Practice Sheet

Creating Nominal Variables.
Examples: Gender (Male, Female), Colors (Red, Blue, Green), or Types of Fruits.
Visualization: Bar chart or Pie chart.
Analysis: Frequency counts, mode, chi-square tests.

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Ordinal Scale

Data with a meaningful order but unequal intervals.








Image source: Voxco

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
ü§Ø Practice Sheet

Creating Ordinal Variables.
Examples: Education level (High School, Bachelor‚Äôs, Master‚Äôs, Ph.D.), Customer satisfaction (Poor, Fair, Good, Excellent).
Visualization: Bar chart or Box plot.
Analysis: Median, rank correlation.

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Interval Scale

Ordered data with equal intervals but no true zero point.








Image source: Voxco

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
ü§Ø Practice Sheet

Creating Interval Variables
Examples: Temperature in Celsius or Fahrenheit, IQ scores.
Visualization: Histogram, Line graph.
Analysis: Mean, standard deviation, correlation, regression.

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Ratio Scale

Ordered data with equal intervals and a true zero point.








Image source: Voxco

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
ü§Ø Practice Sheet

Creating ratio Variables
Examples: Weight, Height, Income, Age.
Visualization: Histogram, Scatter plot.
Analysis: All statistical methods (mean, median, mode, ratio comparisons).

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Different Types of Scales



Image source: Voxco

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Discrete Variables



Represent countable values, often whole numbers.
Examples: Number of students, dice rolls, cars in a parking lot.










Image source: Allison Horst

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
Continuous Variables



Represent measureable values, including fractions or decimals.
Examples: Height, weight, time, temperature.










Image source: Allison Horst

title: SCALES OFMEASUREMENT
text:
ü§Ø Practice Sheet

Discrete Variables, visualization and analysis.
Continuous Variables, visualization and analysis.
Combining Discrete and Continuous Variables.

üí° Tips for variable selection

Use names() function to see the exact names and the order of the variables.
Use : operator to select the range of variables.

  select(island : flipper_length_mm)


Use location value of the variable.


penguins |> 
  select(3 : 7)


Use - operator to not to select the range of variables.

penguins |>

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Download & Install

‚úÖ R Software, https://cloud.r-project.org/
‚úÖ RStudio IDE, https://posit.co/products/open-source/rstudio/?sid=1
‚úÖ Quarto, https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
RStudio

‚úÖ Create RStudio Project in your computer
‚úÖ Create quarto document
‚úÖ Create folder data & save file penguins.csv

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Data: penguins
Live on three island: Biscoe, Dream, & Torgersen.













Source: palmerpenguins

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)


‚Äúhow to use visualization and transformation to explore your data in a systematic way‚Äù



Source: R for Data Science (2e)

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üì¶ Step 1: R Packages

Install R Packages only once:

```{r}
install.packages("palmerpenguins") # to get data
install.packages("tidyverse")      # to collection of R pkgs
install.packages("skimr")          # summary of data  
install.packages("janitor")        # data cleaning
```


Call/load R packages

```{r}
library(palmerpenguins)
library(tidyverse)
library(skimr)
library(janitor)
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üìÅ Step 2: Import the Dataset
You can import from CSV, Excel, or other sources.


```{r}
library(readr)
penguins <- read_csv("session-1/practice/data/penguins.csv", 
    col_types = cols(sex = col_factor(levels = c("male", 
        "female"))))
View(penguins)
```


```{r}
# Replace with your actual file path
data <- read_csv("your_dataset.csv")   
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Data Structure




Source: R for Data Science (2e)

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üìä Step 3: Explore the Data Structure


```{r}
dim(data)          # Dimensions (rows & columns)

names(data)        # Column names

spec(data)         # columns specifications

head(data)         # First few rows

glimpse(data)      # Compact structure

str(data)          # Structure
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Check Data for


Missing values
Duplicate rows
Inconsistent column names

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
‚úÖ Step 4: Transform & Clean the Data

TransformSummaryMissing Values



```{r}
library(readr)

penguins <- read_csv("data/penguins.csv", 
    col_types = cols(sex = col_factor(levels = c("male", "female")),
                     species = col_factor(levels = c("Chinstrap",
                                                     "Gentoo",
                                                     "Adelie")),
                     island  = col_factor(levels = c("Biscoe",
                                                     "Dream",
                                                     "Torgersen"))
                     ))
```





```{r}
summary(penguins)         #basic summary
```




```{r}
sum(is.na(penguins))                 # Total missing values
colSums(is.na(penguins))             # Total column wise missing values       
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Variation

‚ÄúIt is the tendency of the values of a variable to change from measurement to measurement or across different subjects or at different times.‚Äù
‚ÄúEvery variable has its own pattern of variation, which can reveal interesting information about how it varies between measurements on the same observation as well as across observations.‚Äù



Source: R for Data Science (2e)

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
Variation Types

What type of variation occurs within my variables?
What type of co-variation occurs between my variables?

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üìà Step 5: Univariate Analysis

Explore each variable individually


Numerical variablesCategorical variables



```{r}
summary(data$variable)
hist(data$variable, main="Mass Distribution", col="lightblue")
```

Use ggplot2 for more control

```{r}
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "skyblue", bins = 30, color = "white") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Body Mass (g)", x = "Body Mass (g)") +
  theme_minimal()
```




```{r}
table(data$variable)
barplot(table(data$variable), col="pink", main="Species Count")
```

Use ggplot2 for more control

```{r}
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Penguin Species Count") +
  theme_minimal()
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üîÅ Step 6: Bivariate Analysis

Explore relationships between variables


Numeric vs Numeric:Numeric vs Categorical



```{r}
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Flipper Length vs Body Mass") +
  theme_minimal()
```




```{r}
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Body Mass by Species") +
  theme_minimal()
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üìå Step 7: Summary Statistics


```{r}
skimr::skim(data)         # Rich summary
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üìâ Step 8: Outlier Detection

An outlier is a data point that differs markedly from the rest of the data.




```{r}
ggplot(penguins, aes(y = body_mass_g, x = species, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Outliers in Body Mass by Species") +
  theme_minimal()
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üßπ Step 9: Handle Missing Data

(if needed)

Fill missing valuesRemove missing values



```{r}
# Fill missing values
penguins$body_mass_g[is.na(penguins$body_mass_g)] <- median(penguins$body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE)

summary(penguins$body_mass_g)
```




```{r}
# Remove rows with missing data
penguins_clean <- penguins %>% drop_na()
dim(penguins_clean)
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üßæ Step 10: Save Cleaned Data


```{r}
write.csv(data_clean, "cleaned_data.csv")
```

title: EXPLORINGYOUR DATA
text:
üéØ Learnings

Installing R, RStudio, Quarto & R packages.
Import & export of Data
View summary & structure of data
Table & plots to see pattern in data
Treating missing & outlier values

title: DATA  VISUALIZATION
text:
Common Mistakes

Make sure that every ( is matched with a ) and every " is paired with another ".
Console shows no results but a + sign that means your code is incomplete and R is waiting for you to complete the code.
in ggplot + has to come at the end of the line, not the start

    y = "Bill depth (mm)"
  ) +
  theme_clean() +
  scale_color_manual(values = wes_palette("BottleRocket2", n = 3))

ggsave("penguins-plot.pdf")
